sections.doco:title: Differential invariants and contact classification of ordinary differential equations
sections.doco:abstract:
In this work a new approach for classification of ordinary
differential equations is suggested. The field of differential
invariants is described, basic differential invariants are found,
and contact classification of ordinary differential equations in
terms of these invariants is obtained.
sections.doco:subtitle: Differential invariants and contact classification ...
sections.doco:keywords:
Ordinary differential equations, jet space, contact
pseudogroup, differential invariant
sections.doco:introduction:
The problem of classification of ordinary differential equations
with respect to the contact or point transformations is one of the
most important problems in the theory of differential equations. It
seems that the most interesting one is the case of differential
equations of type
\begin{equation}\label{eq.diff.ur.}
y^{(n)}=f(x,y,y',\ldots,y^{(n-1)}).
\end{equation}
The first results in this area were obtained by Sophus Lie:

1) \emph{ordinary differential equation (\ref{eq.diff.ur.}) of the
first order in neighbourhood of regular point is point-equivalent to
the equation $y'=0$};

2) \emph{ordinary differential equation (\ref{eq.diff.ur.}) of the
second order in neighbourhood of regular point is contact-equivalent
to the equation $y''=0$}.
\noindent Hence, it is interesting to study contact classification of
differential equations~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}), when $n\geqslant 3$, and
point classification when $n\geqslant 2$.

Point classification of regular equations~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}) of
order 2 was obtained by Tresse (see~\cite{Tresse}). In modern terms
this result was rewritten by Kruglikov (see~\cite{Krugl}).
Non-regular case of differential equations
$$y''=a_0(x,y)(y')^3+a_1(x,y)(y')^2+a_2(x,y)y'+a_3(x,y),$$ was
studied by Lie, Tresse, Cartan, Liuville, etc. (see, for example,
\cite{Yuma20der}).
Contact classification for third-order equations was studied by
Chern (see~\cite{Chern}), and for forth-order equations -- by Chen
and Lee (see~\cite{Chen}). But they didn't find all differential
invariants for these equations. Moreover, it seems, that method they
used can not be applied on differential equations of higher order.
Dubrov in~\cite{Dub1} constructed set of sub-differential invariants
for differential equations~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}) of arbitrary order.
Using these invariants he solved problem of contact trivialization
of differential equations~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}). Then in~\cite{Dubrov}
he obtained set of sub-differential invariants for systems of
differential equations of arbitrary order.
Finally, Dubrov, Komrakov and Morimoto constructed the Cartan
connection associated with every differential equation
(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}) (and, more generally, with every holonomic
system of differential equations), and reduced the contact
equivalence problem to the classical problem of equivalence of
$\{e\}$-structures. So, the equivalence problem of ordinary
differential equations (\ref{eq.diff.ur.}) can be solved in terms of
$\{e\}$-structures.
Nevertheless, another important problem in this area was still open.
Namely, \emph{how can the differential invariant field of the action
of contact pseudogroup on differential equations (\ref{eq.diff.ur.})
be described}?

In this work we solve this problem for regular differential
equations of arbitrary order $n\geqslant 3$. We obtain number of
differential invariants of these equations and construct set of
dependencies between them, which uniquely determines class of
contact equivalence of a given differential
equation~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}). Also with the help of this
classification we find differential invariants and operators, which
generate all field of differential invariants.

The author is grateful to V. Lychagin for valuable remarks and for
attention to this paper.
doco:chapter:
Let $J^n\mathbb{R}$ be $n$-jet space (here $n\geqslant 2$) of a
function $y\colon \mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$(all necessary details
can be found in~\cite{Alex_Vin_Lych}). Denote by
$(x,y,p_1,p_2,\ldots,p_n)$ canonical coordinates in this space. Let
also
$$\omega_0:=dy-p_1dx, \quad \omega_1:=dp_1-p_2dx \quad\ldots \quad
\omega_{n-1}:=dp_{n-1}-p_ndx$$ be \emph{Cartan forms}. Distribution
generated by these forms is called \emph{Cartan distribution}.
Recall that \emph{contact transformation} on $n$-jet space
$J^n\mathbb{R}$ is diffeomorphism, which preserves Cartan
distribution. According to Lie--Becklund theorem
(see~\cite{Alex_Vin_Lych}), all such transformations are
prolongations of contact transformations in 1-jet space
$J^1\mathbb{R}$.
We describe these transformations in infinitesimal form. Namely,
each smooth function $\varphi\in C^\infty(J^1\mathbb{R})$ generates
contact vector field
$
X_\varphi:=-\varphi_p\frac{\partial}{\partial x} +
(\varphi-p\varphi_p)\frac{\partial}{\partial y}
+(\varphi_x+p\varphi_y)\frac{\partial}{\partial p}
$
on 1-jet space $J^1\mathbb{R}$(here $p:=p_1$). Moreover, each
contact vector field on $J^1\mathbb{R}$ is obtained by this
construction. Note that $\omega_0(X_\varphi)=\varphi$. Function
$\varphi$ is called \emph{generating function} of contact vector
field $X_\varphi$.

All contact vector fields in space $J^n\mathbb{R}$ can be written in
the following form:
\begin{equation}\label{eq.prolong.contact}
X_\varphi^{(n-1)}=-\varphi_p\frac{d}{d x}\Big|_{J^n\mathbb{R}} +
\sum\limits_{k=0}^n \Big(\frac{d^k}{dx^k}\Big)\Big|_{J^n\mathbb{R}}
(\varphi)\cdot \frac{\partial}{\partial p_k}.
\end{equation}
We denote pseudogroup of contact transformations of 1-jet space
$J^1\mathbb{R}$ by $G_{\mathrm{cont}}$ and prolongation of this
pseudogroup in $n$-jet space -- by $G_{\mathrm{cont}}^{(n-1)}$. In
is clear that the action of pseudogroup $G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$
preserver class of differential equations~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}).

Consider natural bundle $\pi_{n,n-1}\colon J^{n}\mathbb{R}\to
J^{n-1}\mathbb{R}$. Smooth sections of this bundle can be considered
as differential equations~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}). Hence, analytic
problem of contact classification of differential
equations~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}) is reduced to geometric problem of
classification of smooth sections of bundle $\pi_{n,n-1}$ with
respect to the contact pseudogroup action.

So, let us consider the action of pseudogroup
$G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$ on module $\Gamma(\pi_{n,n-1})$ of
smooth sections of bundle $\pi_{n,n-1}$. To classify the orbits of
this action we use methods from theory of differential invariants.
First of all we introduce necessary definitions and notations.

Let $f\in \Gamma(\pi_{n,n-1})$ be an arbitrary section. Denote
$k$-jet space of such sections by $\mathbf{J}^k$. Pseudogroup
$G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$ acts on base $\mathbf{J}^0$. This action
canonically prolongs to the action on all $k$-jet spaces
$\mathbf{J}^k$(see~\cite{Alex_Vin_Lych}).
Recall that rational $G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$-invariant function
������� $I$ on space $\mathbf{J}^k$ is called \emph{differential
invariant of order $\leqslant k$}, and combination of total
derivations with rational coefficients is called \emph{invariant
derivation}, if it commutes with the action of pseudogroup
$G^{(n)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$(general theorems on rational differential
invariants of pseudogroup actions can be found in~\cite{Krug_Lych}).

\begin{remark}{\it Action of pseudogroup $G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$ is algebraic in
sense of~\cite{Krug_Lych}}.
\end{remark}
We construct differential invariant and invariant derivation of
pseudogroup $G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$ for all $n\geqslant 3$(idea
of such computation of differential invariants was suggested by
Kruglikov and Lychagin in~\cite[Appendix A]{Krugl}).

Fix an arbitrary $(n-2)$-jet $\theta_{n-2}$ general position and
fiber $V_{\theta_{n-2}}$ of natural projection $\pi_{n-1,n-2}\colon
J^{n-1}\mathbb{R}\to J^{n-2}\mathbb{R}$. Let
$G_{\theta_{n-2}}\subset G_{\mathrm{cont}}^{(n-2)}$ be the
stabilizer of jet $\theta_{n-2}$. It acts on fiber
$V_{\theta_{n-2}}$. It is clear that differential invariants of
$G_{\theta_{n-2}}$-action on the smooth functions on fiber
$V_{\theta_{n-2}}$ are prolonged by differential invariants of
$G_{\mathrm{cont}}^{(n-1)}$-action on sections from
$\Gamma(\pi_{n,n-1})$. On the other hand group $G_{\theta_{n-2}}$ is
finite-dimension. Hence, it is much easier to calculate
$G_{\theta_{n-2}}$-invariants instead of
$G_{\mathrm{cont}}^{(n-1)}$-invariants.

Put $u_i := u_{\underbrace{p_{n-1}\ldots p_{n-1}}_i}$ -- coordinates
in jet space $\mathbf{J}^k$ correspond to derivatives with respect
to variables $p_{n-1}$(i.e. these are coordinates of jets of
functions restricted on fiber $V_{\theta_{n-2}}$). Let us consider
three cases.

\subsection{Case $n=3$}\label{razd.point.n=3}
This case is the most difficult one. In some sense it is an analog
of point classification of second order
equations~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}).
Using formula~(\ref{eq.prolong.contact}), we get that Lie algebra
$\mathfrak{g}_{\theta_{1}}$ of stabilizer $G_{\theta_1}$ consists of
vectors fields
$$X=(Ap_2+B)\frac{\partial}{\partial p_2} + (\lambda u +
ap_2^3+bp_2^2+cp_2+d)\frac{\partial}{\partial u}+
\mu\Big(p_2^2\frac{\partial}{\partial p_2} +
3p_2u\frac{\partial}{\partial u}\Big),$$ where $A$, \ldots, $\mu\in
\mathbb{R}$ are constants.

Consider the action of stabilizer $G_{\theta_{1}}$ and its tangent
algebra $\mathfrak{g}_{\theta_1}$ on the smooth functions restricted
on fiber $V_{\theta_1}$. This action was considered by Kruglikov and
Lychagin in~\cite[Appendix A]{Krugl} in problem of point
classification of second order differential equations. According to
their result, function $J_0:=(25u_4^2u_7 +
84u_5^3-105u_4u_5u_6)^2/(5u_4u_6-6u_5^2)^3$ and derivation
$\delta=\frac{u_4(5u_4u_6-6u_5^2)}{25u_4^2u_7 +
84u_5^3-105u_4u_5u_6}\frac{d}{dp_2}$ are
$\mathfrak{g}_{\theta_1}$-invariant. Hence, function $J_0$ and
derivation $\delta$ are $G^{(2)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$-invariant too.

\subsection{Case $n=4$}\label{razd.point.n=4}
As in case $n=3$, we use formula~(\ref{eq.prolong.contact}) and find
vector fields from Lie algebra $\mathfrak{g}_{\theta_2}$ of
stabilizer $G_{\theta_3}$:
$X=(Ap_{3}+B) \frac{\partial}{\partial p_{3}} + (\lambda u + ap_{3}^2+bp_3+c)\frac{\partial}{\partial u},$
where $A$, \ldots, $c\in \mathbb{R}$ are constants. It can be shown
by direct computation that function $J_0:=u_3u_5/u_4^2$ is
differential $\mathfrak{g}_{\theta_3}$-invariant and derivation
$\delta:=\frac{u_3}{u_4}\frac{d}{dp_{3}}$ is
$\mathfrak{g}_{\theta_3}$-invariant. Hence, these objects are
$G^{(3)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$-invariant.

\subsection{Case $n\geqslant 5$}\label{razd.point.n>4}
As in previous cases, we get vector fields from Lie algebra
$\mathfrak{g}_{\theta_{n-2}}$ of stabilizer $G_{\theta_{n-2}}$:
$ X=(Ap_{n-1}+B) \frac{\partial}{\partial p_{n-1}} + (\lambda u + ap_{n-1}+b)\frac{\partial}{\partial u},$
where $A$, \ldots, $b\in \mathbb{R}$ are constants. It can be proved
by direct computations, that function $J_0:=u_2u_4/u_3^2$ is
differential invariant and derivation
$\delta:=\frac{u_2}{u_3}\frac{d}{dp_{n-1}}$ is invariant.

Geometrically ordinary differential equation~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}) can
be considered not just like section of bundle $\pi_{n,n-1}$, but
like one-dimensional distribution (i.e. direction field) in Cartan
distribution of jet space $J^{n-1}\mathbb{R}$. Namely, for each
differential equation $\mathcal{E}$ one can define
\emph{characteristic vector field $\chi$} generated by vector field
$\left.\frac{d}{dx}\right|_{\mathcal{E}}$. In coordinates it can be
written in the following way:
$$\frac{\partial}{\partial x}+p_1\frac{\partial}{\partial y}+
p_2\frac{\partial}{\partial p_1}+\ldots +
p_{n-1}\frac{\partial}{\partial
p_{n-2}}+f(x,y,p_1,\ldots,p_{n-1})\frac{\partial}{\partial
p_{n-1}}.$$
Visa versa, each direction field $\chi$ of such type uniquely
defines differential equation~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}). Hence, two
differential equations $\mathcal{E}_1$ and $\mathcal{E}_2$ are
contact equivalent if and only if corresponding characteristic
direction fields $\chi_1$ and $\chi_2$ are contact equivalent. We
get the following 

\begin{proposition}\label{predl.char.}
1. Direction field $\langle \mathcal{D}\rangle\subset
T\mathbf{J}^\infty$ generated by vector field
$$\mathcal{D}:=\frac{d}{d x}+p_1\frac{d}{d y}+ p_2\frac{d}{d
p_1}+\ldots + p_{n-1}\frac{d}{d p_{n-2}}+u\frac{d}{d p_{n-1}}$$ is
$G_{\mathrm{cont}}^{(n-1)}$-invariant.

2. Two differential equations $\mathcal{E}_1$ and $\mathcal{E}_2$
are contact equivalent if and only if corresponding direction fields
$\langle\mathcal{D}\rangle\mid_{\mathcal{E}_1}$ and
$\langle\mathcal{D}\rangle\mid_{\mathcal{E}_2}$ are contact
equivalent.
\end{proposition}

\label{razd.G_point.action}
Consider $n+1$ differential invariants $J_0, \quad J_1, \quad \ldots
\quad J_{n},$ where $J_i:=\delta^i J_0$(here $J_0$ and $\delta$
correspond to either case $n=3$, or case $n= 4$, or case $n\geqslant
5$). One can build invariant Tresse derivations
(see~\cite{LychFeedBack}) $\nabla_i:=\frac{D}{DJ_i}, \quad
\text{where $i=0$, \ldots, $n$.}$ Note that
$\nabla_j(J_i)=\delta_{ij}$.

\begin{definition}
Section $f\in \Gamma(\pi_{n,n-1})$ is said to be \emph{regular}, if
restrictions of invariants $J_0$, \ldots, $J_n$ on this section are
functionally independent in some area in jet space
$J^{n-1}\mathbb{R}$.
Differential equation~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}) is said to be
\emph{regular}, if corresponding section $f\in \Gamma(\pi_{n,n-1})$
is regular.
\end{definition}
Consider regular section $f\in \Gamma(\pi_{n,n-1})$ and its
$G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$-orbit. Restrictions $J_i(f)$ are smooth
independent functions on an open dance subset in jet space
$J^{n-1}\mathbb{R}$. So, they form coordinate system in
$J^{n-1}\mathbb{R}$. Our aim is to describe the action of
pseudogroup $G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$ on space $\mathbf{J}^0$ in
these coordinates, i.e. we need rewrite condition of preserving
Cartan distribution on $\mathbf{J}^0$ by pseudogroup
$G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$.
Note that Cartan plane is generated by two contact-invariant
direction fields $\langle \mathcal{D}\rangle$ and $\langle
\frac{d}{dp_{n-1}}\rangle$. Hence, action of pseudogroup
$G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$ on base $\mathbf{J}^0$ can be
characterized in the following way: \emph{diffeomorphism
$\varphi\colon \mathbf{J}^0\to\mathbf{J}^0$ is contact if and only
if}$d\varphi(\mathcal{D}) = \lambda\mathcal{D}$ and $
d\varphi\Big(\frac{d}{dp_{n-1}}\Big)=\mu\frac{d}{dp_{n-1}}$, where
$\lambda$, $\mu\in C^\infty(\mathbf{J}^0)$.

Now we can describe action of contact pseudogroup
$G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$ on module $\Gamma(\pi_{n,n-1})$ of
smooth sections in coordinates $J_i(f)$. To do this one should
rewrite vector fields $\frac{d}{dp_{n-1}}$ and $\mathcal{D}$ in
coordinates $J_0$, \ldots, $J_n$:
%\begin{align*}$$
\frac{d}{dp_{n-1}}=\sum\limits_{k=0}^n
\frac{dJ_k}{dp_{n-1}}\nabla_k,\quad \mathcal{D}=\sum\limits_{k=0}^n
\mathcal{D}(J_k)\nabla_k.
$$%\end{align*}%where $\widehat{d}$ is total differentiate%(see~\cite{Alex_Vin_Lych}).
Note that invariant derivation $\delta$ is proportional to
$\frac{d}{dp_{n-1}}$(coefficients of proportion are found in
sections~\ref{razd.point.n=3}--\ref{razd.point.n>4}). So,
multiplying the first relation by corresponding coefficient of
proportion, one get
$\delta= J_1 \nabla_0 + J_2\nabla_1+\ldots+J_{n+1}\nabla_n.$
As vector field $\mathcal{D}$ is sub-invariant of the action of
contact pseudogroup $G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$, then functions
$\mathcal{D}_{k}:=\mathcal{D}(J_k)$ are also sub-invariants of this
action. As these sub-invariants have the same weight, then fractions
$\mathcal{D}_k/\mathcal{D}_l$ are absolute differential invariants.

Now consider restrictions of the components of vector fields
$\delta$ and $\mathcal{D}$ on section $f$. Let us extend these
components in coordinates $J_i(f)$:
%\begin{align*}$$
\mathcal{D}_k(f) = P_k(J_0(f),J_1(f),\ldots,J_{n}(f)), \quad
J_{n+1}(f) = Q(J_0(f),J_1(f),\ldots,J_{n}(f)). $$%\end{align*}
We obtain functions $\mathscr{P}_f\colon J^{n-1}\mathbb{R}\to
\mathbb{R}P^{n}, \quad \mathscr{P}(a)=(P_{0}(a):\ldots:P_{n}(a))$
and $Q_f\colon J^{n-1}\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$(here $a\in
J^{n-1}\mathbb{R}$ is an arbitrary point).

\begin{theorem}\label{th.class.}
Regular sections $f$, $\widetilde{f}\in \Gamma(\pi_{n,n-1})$ (and
corresponding regular differential equations~(\ref{eq.diff.ur.}))
are locally contact equivalent if and only if
$\mathscr{P}_f=\mathscr{P}_{\widetilde{f}}$ and
$Q_f=Q_{\widetilde{f}}.$
\end{theorem}\begin{proof}
It is clear that functions $\mathscr{P}_f$ and $Q_f$ are absolute
$G^{(n-1)}_{\mathrm{cont}}$-invariants. Let us prove the sufficiency
on this condition.
Assume that for two regular sections $f$, $\widetilde{f}\in
\Gamma(\pi_{n,n-1})$ one holds
$\mathscr{P}_f=\mathscr{P}_{\widetilde{f}}$ and
$Q_f=Q_{\widetilde{f}}.$ Consider two coordinate systems
$$S_f:=(J_0(f),J_1(f), \ldots, J_{n}(f))\quad\text{and}\quad
S_{\widetilde{f}}:=(J_0(\widetilde{f}),J_1(\widetilde{f}), \ldots,
J_{n}(\widetilde{f})).$$ Let $\Phi$ be diffeomorphism, that maps
$S_f$ in $S_{\widetilde{f}}$. We prove that $\Phi$ is contact
transformation that maps section $f$ in section $\widetilde{f}$.

(1) As $\mathscr{P}_f=\mathscr{P}_{\widetilde{f}}$, then $\Phi$
preserves characteristic direction field $\langle
\mathcal{D}\rangle$. Hence, according to
Proposition~\ref{predl.char.} it maps section $f$ in section
$\widetilde{f}$.

(2) As $Q_f=Q_{\widetilde{f}}$, then $\Phi$ preserves vector field
$\delta$. So, $\Phi$ preserves direction fields
$\langle\mathcal{D}\rangle$ and $\langle\delta\rangle$, which
generate Cartan distribution $\mathcal{C}$. Hence it is contact.

It follows from (1) and (2) that $\Phi\in G_{\mathrm{cont}}^{(n-1)}$
and $\Phi\circ f=\widetilde{f}$.
\end{proof}
Next results immediately follow from Theorem~\ref{th.class.}.

\begin{theorem}
Field of differential invariants of contact pseudogroup
$G_{\mathrm{cont}}^{(n-1)}$ action on space $\mathbf{J}^\infty$
generates by differential invariant $J_0$, invariant derivation
$\delta$ and invariant differential operator
%\begin{align*}
$$
\Delta\colon C^\infty(\mathbf{J}^\infty)\to
C^\infty(\mathbf{J}^\infty, \mathbb{R}^n), \quad \Delta(F) =
\Big(\frac{\mathcal{D}(\delta(F))}{\mathcal{D}(F)},
\frac{\mathcal{D}(\delta^2(F))}{\mathcal{D}(F)},\ldots,
\frac{\mathcal{D}(\delta^{n}(F))}{\mathcal{D}(F)}\Big).
$$%\end{align*}
\end{theorem}%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
